facts.text: State of West Bengal appealed to Supreme Court against Full Bench judgment of Calcutta High Court quashing conviction of respondent by Special Court

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by the State of West Bengal from a judgment of a Full Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta quashing the conviction of the respondent by the Special Court established under section 3 of the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949, Ordinance No. 3 of 1949 which was replaced in March, 1950, by the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950, West Bengal Act X of 1950 hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Respondent and 49 other persons charged with various offences committed during raid as armed gang on Jessop Factory at Dum Dum

anchor.surface_text: The respondent and 49 other persons were charged with various offences alleged to have been committed by them in the course of their raid as an armed gang on a certain factory known as the Jessop Factory at Dum Dum, and they were convicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a notification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 5 (1) of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent and 49 others convicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by Special Court

anchor.surface_text: and they were convicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a notification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 5 (1) of the Act. Thereupon the respondent applied to the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the conviction and sentence on the ground that the Special Court had no jurisdiction to try the case inasmuch as section 5 (1), under which it was sent to that Court for trial, was unconstitutional and void under article 13 (2) as it denied to the respondent the equal protection of the laws enjoined by article 14.

facts.text: Case sent to Special Court by Governor of West Bengal by notification dated 26th January 1950 under section 5(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a notification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 5 (1) of the Act. Thereupon the respondent applied to the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the conviction and sentence on the ground that the Special Court had no jurisdiction to try the case inasmuch as section 5 (1), under which it was sent to that Court for trial, was unconstitutional and void under article 13 (2) as it denied to the respondent the equal protection of the laws enjoined by article 14.

facts.text: West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance 1949 (No. 3 of 1949) replaced in March 1950 by West Bengal Special Courts Act 1950 (Act X of 1950)

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, C.J. This is an appeal by the State of West Bengal from a judgment of a Full Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta quashing the conviction of the respondent by the Special Court established under section 3 of the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949, Ordinance No. 3 of 1949 which was replaced in March, 1950, by the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950, West Bengal Act X of 1950 hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Full Bench of Calcutta High Court quashed conviction and directed trial according to law

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by a Full Bench consisting of the Chief Justice and four other Judges quashed the conviction and directed the trial of the respondent and the other accused persons according to law. Hence the appeal. The Act is intituled An Act to provide for the speedier trial of certain offences, and the preamble declares that it is expedient to provide for the speedier trial of certain offences.

facts.text: Respondent applied to High Court under Article 226 for writ of certiorari quashing conviction on ground of lack of jurisdiction due to unconstitutionality of section 5(1)

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent applied to the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the conviction and sentence on the ground that the Special Court had no jurisdiction to try the case inasmuch as section 5 (1), under which it was sent to that Court for trial, was unconstitutional and void under article 13 (2) as it denied to the respondent the equal protection of the laws enjoined by article 14.

facts.text: Raid on Jessop Factory at Dum Dum took place on February 26, 1949 by armed gang including Anwar Ali Sarkar and 49 others

anchor.surface_text: Anwar Ali Sarkar, who is the respondent in Appeal No. 297, along with 49 other persons, were the accused in what is known as Dum Dum Factory Raid case, where crimes of the utmost brutality were committed by an armed gang of men on the factory of Messrs. Jessop and Company at Dum Dum. The raid took place on February 26, 1949.

facts.text: Special Judge convicted accused under various sections of Indian Penal Code on 31st March 1951, some to transportation for life

anchor.surface_text: The trial lasted for several months and by his judgment dated the 31st of March, 1951, the Special Judge convicted the accused under various sections of the Indian Penal Code, some of them being sentenced to transportation for life, while others were sentenced to undergo various terms of imprisonment according to the gravity of their offence.

facts.text: Notification dated 25th January 1950 directed case of Anwar Ali and 49 co-accused to be tried by Special Judge S.N. Guha Roy

anchor.surface_text: On 25th of January, 1950, the State Government by a notification directed that the case of Anwar Ali and his 49 co-accused should be tried by Mr. S. N. Guha Roy in accordance with the provisions of the Ordinance.

facts.text: West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance promulgated on 17th August 1949

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949, which was later replaced by the impugned Act West Bengal Special Courts Act X of 1950, to be hereinafter referred to as the Act , was a valid Ordinance when it was promulgated on the 17th August, 1949.

facts.text: West Bengal Special Courts Act came into effect on 15th March 1950

anchor.surface_text: The Act, which came into effect on the 15th March, 1950, is a verbatim reproduction of the earlier Ordinance

facts.text: Notification covered five more cases besides Anwar Ali's case, all related to armed raid on Jessop Co.

anchor.surface_text: The notification by which the case of Anwar Ali Sirkar  the respondent herein  was directed to be tried by the special court did not relate merely to that case but covered five more cases in each of which the accused were several in number.

facts.text: Crimes of utmost brutality committed on large scale during raid on Jessop premises

anchor.surface_text: All these cases related to the armed raid on the premises of Jessop Co. in the course of which crimes of the utmost brutality were committed on a large scale and to incidents following the raid.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Special Bench judgment dated 28th August 1951 quashed proceedings

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals are directed against the judgment of a Special Bench of the Calcutta High Court dated the 28th of August, 1951

facts.text: Formal complaint lodged before Special Judge on April 2, 1950 against 50 persons

anchor.surface_text: A formal complaint was lodged before the Special Judge in respect of these 50 persons on April 2, 1950, that is to say, after the Special Courts Act was passed, superseding the Ordinance.

facts.text: Accused arrested some time after Ordinance promulgated on August 17, 1949

anchor.surface_text: The accused or most of them were arrested some time after the Ordinance was promulgated.

facts.text: State Government appointed S.N. Guha Roy as Special Judge on October 28, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On October 28, 1949, when the Ordinance was still in force, the West Bengal Government appointed Shri S. N. Guha Roy, who was then the Sessions Judge of Alipore, a Special Judge, with powers to try cases under the Ordinance.

facts.text: Gajen Mali and 5 others tried before Special Judge M. Bhattacharya for murder and conspiracy

anchor.surface_text: On 21st of May following, a similar application for quashing a pending criminal trial was filed by Gajen Mali the respondent in the other appeal, who along with 5 other persons is being tried for offences of murder and conspiracy to murder before Mr. M. Bhattacharya, another Special Judge

holdings.text: Section 5(1) of the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950 is unconstitutional and void under Article 14 to the extent it empowers the State Government to direct any individual case to a Special Court for trial as it vests arbitrary and unfettered power leading to discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts, which are not controverted, may be shortly stated as follows. On August 17, 1949, an Ordinance, known as the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, was promulgated by the Governor of West Bengal under section 88 of the Government of India Act, 1935.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unfettered discretion to executive without guidelines for classification violates equal protection; no reasonable basis or nexus to object of speedier trial; leads to possible anomalous treatment of similar cases.

holdings.text: Even construing Section 5(1) with preamble limiting to cases requiring speedier trial, it violates Article 14 as 'speedier trial' is vague criterion without objective test for classification.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949, which was later replaced by the impugned Act West Bengal Special Courts Act X of 1950, to be hereinafter referred to as the Act , was a valid Ordinance when it was promulgated on the 17th August, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble cannot save vague classification; no intelligible differentia or rational nexus; possibility of discriminatory application inherent.

holdings.text: The notification directing these cases to Special Court is not discriminatory under Article 14 as cases involve utmost brutality and organized revolt warranting speedier trial.

anchor.surface_text: That brings us to the consideration of the validity of the notification issued in the present case. ... All these cases related to the armed raid on the premises of Jessop Co. in the course of which crimes of the utmost brutality were committed on a large scale

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show special circumstances justifying reference despite general invalidity of provision; no purposeful discrimination shown.

holdings.text: Section 5(1) does not involve excessive delegation of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: that it involves excessive delegation of legislative authority amounting to its abdication in so far as it gives unfettered discretion to the executive, without laying down any standard or rules of guidance, to make use of the procedure laid down by it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from delegation cases; primary issue is Art14 discrimination, not abdication.

holdings.text: Special procedure under the Act does not derogate from essential requirements of fair trial.

anchor.surface_text: While some of these departures from the normal procedure might, in practice, operate in some respects to the disadvantage of persons tried before the Special Court, it cannot be said that they derogate from the essential requirements of a fair and impartial trial

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deviations like no committal, no jury shorten trial but preserve fairness; calculated for expedition.

holdings.text: A law conferring discretionary power is invalid under Article 14 if it permits arbitrary discrimination even if capable of non-discriminatory application.

anchor.surface_text: When an Act gives power which may and can offend against a provision or provisions of the Constitution such an Act is ultra vires though it could be administered so as not to offend against the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Possibility of abuse where no guidelines renders law discriminatory; presumption against arbitrariness insufficient.

holdings.text: Section 5(1) read with preamble empowers reference only of cases requiring speedier trial and is constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of construction applicable here is perhaps nowhere better stated than by Lord Tenterden C.J. in Halton v. Cove (1830) 1 B & Ad. 538, 558 ... the preamble affords a good clue to discover what that object was.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction limits discretion; expected bona fide exercise for object.

holdings.text: The appeals should be dismissed as Section 5(1) offends Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals are directed against the judgment of a Special Bench of the Calcutta High Court dated the 28th of August, 1951

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of arbitrary power, anomalous procedures, no classification.

justification_sets.label: Maneka Gandhi Framework (Due Process) support defeaters

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeals fail and are dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; High Court judgment upheld quashing convictions and declaring section 5(1) of West Bengal Special Courts Act unconstitutional
